metadata.h1: 🧱 4 Steps to Easily Allocate Resources with Python & Bin Packing

all_paragraphs: In this article, we will play with Python and the binpacking package to solve one of the most common NP-hard problems: the Bin Packing Problem. 🗑️
Specifically, through a greedy approach, we will staff m number of resources on n number of projects relying on their value/score. Let’s start!
Suppose you have m items of different weight (or value) that you need to fit into n equal balanced bins (Fig.1).
💡 This is what is usually called Bin Packing Problem.

The BPP is classified by computational complexity theory as a NP-hard problem which, to make it short, is as difficult as the most difficult problem solvable in a Non-deterministic Polynomial time (NP problem).
Although these words may seem bordering on understanding (I can swear to you that there are no typing errors in the previous sentences), the Bin Packing Problem often occurs in everyday life.

Yes. As the name suggests the Bin Packing Problem comes up every time we have to “fill” something with something else.As you can imagine there are n-dimensional variants that take into account other useful information such as volume or cost (Knapsack Problem).

Here is one of my favorite steps: the parameters definition.
🗑️ Let’s firstly define the number of bins we want, then the dictionary containing the estimated/measured value of the resources at our disposal.
To each key of the dictionary will correspond the estimation of the contribution value of that resource. Yes, a sort of score.
Given the extreme complexity in the search for the optimal solution in NP-hard problems, we could not succeed without a greedy approach. Here comes into play the binpacking package.

🧮 Greedy algorithms allow to get to solutions of difficult problems in an approximate but acceptable way. In short, with greedy approaches, we pay the solution of the problem at the expense of its accuracy.
The use of the package is extremely easy.
Done! Incredibly painless. Let’s try to visualize the result in a different way cleaning up the values using a list comprehension.
We staffed all the resources and created 6 (probably) balanced groups.
Ok, but now it’s time to see how the algorithm performed. Let’s find out if the groups are truly balanced between them.
What we expect are 6 groups each with a total value very close to the sum of the total values divided by the number of groups.
So it’s easy to calculate the ideal value per group and the values of the found groups.
📊 Let’s try to show them.
Here is the graph: the red horizontal line represents the ideal average desired value per each group (Fig.2).
Ta daa! As we expected we built 6 balanced groups. Each group has in fact a score very close the idealValue (11.666). I think the goal is (approximately) achieved. 🥳
Remember, in fact, that what we have obtained is a solution compatible with our problem but not optimal, since we used a greedy algorithm.

In short, the Bin Packing Problem is really very common in everyday life.Greedy approaches like the one just seen (bin packing can be solved by using different greedy approaches) can come useful in a good set of occasions especially if they are extremely easy to implement.

Some food for thought? What if we want to try to take into account the cost of items? What if we also want to integrate a 2nd or 3rd dimension?Probably the simple 1D Bin Packing would fit a bit tight.
I think we should talk about it in the next articles… So, stay tuned! 😉
